title: How to Photograph a Rainbow

steps.headline: Have your camera ready.
steps.description: These days, that is easy, because most of us have our cell phones handy.

steps.headline: Know the conditions that will create a rainbow.
steps.description: What you will be looking for are falling water drops and bright sunlight. This is usually after a rainstorm or near a water sprinkler. Also, a waterfall, fountain, or a geyser are just a few other suggestions where you might get some quality shots. If possible, see if you can change your perspective to get a better, brighter photo.

steps.headline: Find something in the foreground to add interest.
steps.description: Without that, it's just another picture of a rainbow. Try to include both of the 'endpoints' of the rainbow; that is where it appears to hit the ground. That being said, if you have an interesting shot with just the single end, shoot it.

steps.headline: Keep your eye out for multiple rainbows.
steps.description: Where there is one, there is, quite often, two of them. If you are using a camera, have a polarizing filter. This has the effect of reducing exposure, if needed, to make the rainbow stand out.

steps.headline: Consider bracketing your photograph.
steps.description: Some cameras and cell phones come with the ability to bracket your images.

steps.headline: Keep your composition in mind.
steps.description: Consider the 'rules' of photography and then apply them as you see fit.

steps.headline: Pull over or take advantage of a stoplight.
steps.description: Safety is important. You really don't want to be 'that person' who caused a major collision because you were trying to snap a great photo while driving.

steps.headline: Turn off the car or get out of it.
steps.description: The engine causes vibrations that may not seem like much, but they can be a problem for the quality of your image.

steps.headline: Use applicable apps.
steps.description: If you are using a cell phone, there are apps that will allow you to have more control over your photograph. Doing things like reducing exposure can really brighten up your shot if the circumstances aren't quite right.

steps.headline: Have some way of stabilizing your camera.
steps.description: Perhaps, keep a pillow, beanbag, or a small tripod in the car, ready to go.
